title: A Sparkle Of December Magic (2025 Wallpapers Edition)
text:
A Sparkle Of December Magic (2025 Wallpapers Edition)

With December just around the corner, how about some new desktop wallpapers to welcome the last month of the year ‚Äî and the holiday season, if you‚Äôre celebrating? Our latest edition of monthly wallpapers has got you covered. Enjoy!

title: The Accessibility Problem With Authentication Methods Like CAPTCHA
text:
The Accessibility Problem With Authentication Methods Like CAPTCHA

CAPTCHAs were meant to keep bots out, but too often, they lock people with disabilities out, too. From image classification to click-based tests, many ‚Äúhuman checks‚Äù are anything but inclusive. There‚Äôs no universal solution, but understanding real user needs is where accessibility truly starts.

title: Design System Culture: What It Is And Why It Matters (Excerpt)
text: Design System Culture: What It Is And Why It Matters (Excerpt) We‚Äôre so happy to announce that ‚ÄúMaturing Design Systems‚Äù‚Äîa Smashing book by Ben Callahan — will soon be joining the Smashing Library! Ben‚Äôs insights and advice are so powerful, we thought you might like to read an excerpt from the book. Subscribe to our Smashing newsletter to be notified when orders are open.

title: Designing For Stress And Emergency
text: Designing For Stress And Emergency Practical guidelines on designing time-critical products that prevent errors and improve accuracy. Part of the Measure UX & Design Impact (use the code üéü IMPACT to save 20% off today). With a live UX training starting next week.

title: Keyframes Tokens: Standardizing Animation Across Projects
text:
Keyframes Tokens: Standardizing Animation Across Projects

Animations can be one of the most joyful parts of building interfaces, but without structure, they can also become one of the biggest sources of frustration. By consolidating and standardizing keyframes, you take something that is usually messy and hard to manage and turn it into a clear, predictable system.

title: From Chaos To Clarity: Simplifying Server Management With AI And Automation
text:
From Chaos To Clarity: Simplifying Server Management With AI And Automation

Server chaos doesn‚Äôt have to be the norm. AI-ready infrastructure and automation can bring clarity, performance, and focus back to your web work.

title: CSS Gamepad API Visual Debugging With CSS Layers
text:
CSS Gamepad API Visual Debugging With CSS Layers

Debugging controllers can be a real pain. Here‚Äôs a deep dive into how CSS helps clean it up and how to build a reusable visual debugger for your own projects.

title: Older Tech In The Browser Stack
text:
Older Tech In The Browser Stack

There are many existing web features and technologies in the wild that you may never touch directly in your day-to-day work. Perhaps you‚Äôre fairly new to web development and are simply unaware of them because you‚Äôre steeped in the abstraction of a specific framework that doesn‚Äôt require you to know it deeply, or even at all. Bryan Rasmussen looks specifically at XPath and demonstrates how it can be used alongside CSS to query elements.

title: Effectively Monitoring Web Performance
text:
Effectively Monitoring Web Performance

There are lots of tips for [improving your website performance](https://www.debugbear.com/blog/improve-website-performance?utm_campaign=sm-10). But even if you follow all of the advice, are you able to maintain an optimized site? And are you targeting the right pages? Matt Zeunert outlines an effective strategy for web performance optimization and explains the roles that different types of data play in it.

title: Smashing Animations Part 6: Magnificent SVGs¬†With `<use>`¬†And CSS Custom Properties
text:
Smashing Animations Part 6: Magnificent SVGs¬†With `<use>`¬†And CSS Custom Properties

SVG is one of those web technologies that‚Äôs both elegant and, at times, infuriating. In this article, pioneering author and web designer Andy Clarke explains his technique for animating SVG elements that are hidden in the Shadow DOM.

title: Six Key Components of UX Strategy
text: Six Key Components of UX Strategy Let‚Äôs dive into the building blocks of UX strategy and see how it speaks the language of product and business strategy to create user value while achieving company goals. Part of the Measure UX & Design Impact (use the code üéü IMPACT to save 20% off today).

title: How To Leverage Component Variants In Penpot
text: How To Leverage Component Variants In Penpot With component variants, design systems become more flexible, letting you reuse the same component while adapting its look or state with ease. In this article, Daniel Schwarz demonstrates how design tokens can be leveraged to manage components and their variations using Penpot, the open-source tool built for scalable, consistent design.

title: Fading Light And Falling Leaves (November 2025 Wallpapers Edition)
text:
Fading Light And Falling Leaves (November 2025 Wallpapers Edition)

The new month is just around the corner, and that means: It‚Äôs time for some new desktop wallpapers! All of them are designed by the community for the community and can be downloaded for free. Enjoy!

title: JavaScript For Everyone: Iterators
text:
JavaScript For Everyone: Iterators

Here is a lesson on Iterators. Iterables implement the iterable iteration interface, and iterators implement the iterator iteration interface. Sounds confusing? Mat breaks it all down in the article.

title: Ambient Animations In Web Design: Practical Applications (Part 2)
text:
Ambient Animations In Web Design: Practical Applications (Part 2)

Motion can be tricky: too much distracts, too little feels flat. Ambient animations sit in the middle. They‚Äôre subtle, slow-moving details that add atmosphere without stealing the show. In part two of his series, web design pioneer Andy Clarke shows how ambient animations can add personality to any website design.

title: Design critiques, mandated screen addiction, locksmith stickers, accessibility lessons
text:
Design critiques, mandated screen addiction, locksmith stickers, accessibility lessons

Weekly curated resources for designers‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthinkers and¬†makers.

‚ÄúA critique is not a governance mechanism, nor is it a group brainstorming session. It‚Äôs a necessary collision. It‚Äôs the intentional application of adversarial thought to something that isn‚Äôt finished yet. Its sole purpose is to pressure-test the underlying assumptions. Ultimately, critiques are about injecting constructive doubt into a designer‚Äôs premature certainty before they build too much or go too¬†far.‚Äù

Critique: on elevating craft through critical thinking¬†‚Üí

Editor picks

  • Human engineering ‚Üí
    Doing the right thing should be easy.
    By Michael¬†Parent
  • Is there such thing as Product Design? ‚Üí
    The value of Design in a product organization.
    By danramsden
  • Mandated screen addiction = undemocratic design ‚Üí
    There is a contradiction in digitalization.
    By Sanna¬†Rau

The UX Collective is an independent design publication that elevates unheard design voices and helps designers think more critically about their¬†work.

Color palette pro: customizable palettes in advanced color spaces¬†‚Üí

Make me¬†think

  • Is AI really eating the world? ‚Üí
    ‚ÄúGenerative AI appears to be the next platform shift, or it could break the cycle entirely. The range of outcomes spans from ‚Äújust more software‚Äù to a single unified intelligence that handles everything. The pattern recognition is smart, but I think the current evidence points more clearly toward commoditization than Evans suggests, with value flowing up the stack rather than to model providers.‚Äù
  • The Rosetta Stone of design engineering ‚Üí
    ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always imagined design and engineering as two rails on the same track. They run in parallel, supposedly toward the same product, but they rarely sit at the same spot. Design debt on one side, tech debt on the other, shifting priorities somewhere ahead, and the occasional giant ‚Äòwait what are we building again?‚Äô boulder in the¬†middle.‚Äù
  • To be a leader of systems ‚Üí
    ‚ÄúFirstly, you need to hold in your head the knowledge that you will probably‚Äìno, almost certainly‚Äìfail. You will need to hold that uncomfortableness in your heart and carry it with you always. Never to share, but always to hold. Ground yourself in the impossibilities of what you‚Äôll attempt, lest your hubris lead you to¬†ruin.‚Äù

Little gems this¬†week

Locksmith stickers are annoying, but kind of genius ‚Üí
By Faux¬†Icing

Florence Nightingale on vanity metrics ‚Üí
By Nate¬†Sowder

Dawn of the undead peripheral ‚Üí
By Neel¬†Dozome

Tools and resources

  • A conversation on HMI design ‚Üí
    A series of thought pieces on UI design beyond mobile phones.
    By Ascanio Colonna di¬†Paliano
  • Accessibility lessons ‚Üí
    What an accessibility conference taught me about designing for all.
    By Darren¬†Yeo
  • Invisible users ‚Üí
    The people our design processes forget
    By¬†Dolphia

Support the newsletter

If you find our content helpful, here‚Äôs how you can support¬†us:

  • Check out this week‚Äôs sponsor to support their work¬†too
  • Forward this email to a friend and invite them to subscribe
  • Sponsor an¬†edition

title: The internet needs an AI off switch
text:
The internet needs an AI off switch

People want the human internet¬†back.

Pinterest‚Äôs new AI filter could be the next step in the evolution of the internet. It‚Äôs the first major platform to actually adjust to what a lot of people have been feeling. Our feeds across a broad spectrum of apps are being flooded with low-quality AI slop. The effect is a degradation of trust and an increasing desire to have more control over what we actually see. Pinterest‚Äôs move is the first real signal that platforms are recognizing there‚Äôs a growing problem instead of pretending that AI generated content and design is the¬†future.

While I‚Äôm not proud to say it, I do occasionally scroll TikTok to kill a few brain cells and a few minutes in my day. My partner also sends me TikToks which she says is her love language, which I in turn use to justify the habit. But these days I‚Äôm seeing a trend, there is a stark increase in comments trying to figure out whether a video is AI. We‚Äôre literally becoming reality police in the comments of these feeds. Sometimes it‚Äôs obvious, there‚Äôs that monotoned, programmatically friendly voice playing over a grainy, intentionally retro aesthetic designed to hide AI distortions. But even when it isn‚Äôt obvious, people are suspicious. There‚Äôs a growing paranoia around what to believe and not believe when scrolling through your feeds on Facebook, Instagram, Tiktok and¬†more.

It‚Äôs a painfully predictable side effect of releasing an unregulated video-generation tool that tries its hardest to pass for reality. There are many tools racing towards that meaningless end but the most notable example is Sora. There‚Äôs the famous bouncing bunnies video or the progressive pastor video, that went mainstream and gave Sora some early hype. But to me it seems like the hype has evaporated. I don‚Äôt know a single person who actually uses Sora. Not one. I barely know anyone who even downloaded it! And the people who did opened it once, generated something vaguely cursed, laughed nervously, and then abandoned it.

To me it‚Äôs unsurprising, as it seemed like the main use case for downloading the app was making creepy videos of Sam Altman being mocked in increasingly bizarre and slightly more humiliating situations. Along with a string of racially insensitive videos of MLK making fake speeches, which were eventually disallowed after the very busy ethicist of open AI Olivia Gambelin told the BBC OpenAI that limiting further use of Dr King‚Äôs image was ‚Äúa good step forward‚Äù. Not only were there weird historical recontextualized videos but also blatant copyright infringements of famous characters. Which we all know is a favourite of OpenAI. Videos on Sora are considered a ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù when they reach escape velocity and seep into mainstream content, which is a strange metric for anything, let alone for a CEO who keeps insisting this tech is ‚Äúinevitable.‚Äù

But all of this ‚Äúinevitability‚Äù talk from AI tech CEOs is starting to wear thin. Sure, we exist within certain systems. Yes, capital moves the way capital moves. But companies only have power because users hand it to them. When people walk away and engagement drops the inevitability story starts to look¬†flimsy.

It‚Äôs been a awhile now since the first big wave of AI models started generating shockingly polished visuals. And I‚Äôll be honest: sometimes the results are impressive! But my standards for AI are different from my standards for humans. There is still a huge amount of rich, deeply human art being made every day as well as a huge historical trove to dig through that is fundamentally more interesting because it comes from people with taste and lived experience.

Also the hard truth for AI generated content is that the people who can make beautiful things already are the ones best positioned to make beautiful AI-assisted things. And what are their incentives? Across the board creatives are getting fired because of the threat of AI replacement, why would they be the first to hop onboard to support a tool that‚Äôs literally trying to take their jobs. Right now it seems like lot of AI content online comes from people with no creative background dumping average outputs into the feed. People are trying their hand at it, making something new from nothing, and while I admire the spirit in that the harsh truth is it adds almost¬†nothing.

It turns out making something good that people care about is extremely hard. And making something great is harder still. Great work in my view is inherently collaborative, political, relational. It requires conflict, iteration, and concession. You can‚Äôt flatten all of that into a prompt without losing what makes it resonate. Most recently OpenAI announced that they would be making an AI first movie called Critterz for under 30 million as an attempt to try and show the power of AI in film/animation production. But it does beg the question, why is it that OpenAI has to front the cash here? Maybe it‚Äôs because independent filmmakers aren‚Äôt interested in leveraging this tool? If it was truly a great tool for filmmakers, we would already be hearing about the new voices breaking through the cultural marketplace signalling the importance of this new medium. It ain‚Äôt happening!

Oftentimes when I tell this to AI boosters there‚Äôs this pushback that it‚Äôs only getting better and better, and while yes the fidelity and realism is increasing, I have yet to feel the rumblings of a creative AI revolution. I firmly believe you cannot collapse a lifetime of discipline and taste into a few paragraphs of prompting. You can‚Äôt try and remove collaboration and expect a better product. Yes, I‚Äôve seen beautiful AI imagery, but they are the exceptions, not the rule. And more importantly: no one is asking for more of it, in fact they‚Äôre asking for¬†less.

When people identify a video as AI, it‚Äôs usually to warn others not to trust it. That alone tells you what demand actually looks like. Most social platforms exist on human-generated content and I think the flood of AI slop is not likely to increase engagement. We all buy into this story that AI will optimize for our attention, stimulating the exact parts of our brain to create dopamine zombies and while I don‚Äôt deny that‚Äôs certainly possible, I do think that it‚Äôs actually quite unlikely. There is still no comparison between human content and AI content from a quality perspective.

Pinterest‚Äôs new filter lets users reduce or outright hide AI-generated content. TikTok is now testing a similar feature. And I know I‚Äôll be turning it on the second it becomes available. No one begged for this influx of AI content. It doesn‚Äôt solve a problem that actually existed or if it does, I certainly can‚Äôt put a finger on it. It‚Äôs a novel toy that has overwhelmed entire corners of the internet, suffocating feeds and making us all paranoid and platforms are finally starting to admit it. While they‚Äôll never say ‚Äúour feeds were drowning in AI nonsense and users hated it.‚Äù features speak louder than words. When Pinterest gives you the option to filter out AI, and TikTok rushes to pilot something similar, the message is clear: people want the human internet¬†back.

I have hope that creativity online won‚Äôt be defined by who has the most generative models pumping out piles of content. The novelty of AI is already wearing off and the fatigue is very very real. If platforms want engagement, if they want trust or if they want actual culture to keep happening on their watch, they‚Äôre going to have to give us control over our feeds, including the ability to filter out, reduce, or completely remove AI-generated content.

The internet needs an AI off switch was originally published in UX Collective on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.
